Bio:
Ama Ata Aidoo was born in 1942 in Abeadzi Kyiakor, Ghana. A poet, novelist and playwright, Aidoo attended the Wesley Girls High School and the University of Ghana where she received her bachelor's degree  in 1964. As an undergraduate student, she was invited to the University of Ibidan’s African Writers Workshop, where she met and was influenced by the writers Langston Hughes, Chinua Achebe, Ezekiel Mphahlele, Wole Sokinka, and Christopher Okigbo. Her play The Dilemma of a Ghost was published in 1965 to critical acclaim. She is the author of several novels, plays and collections of poetry including, No Sweetness Here (Longman, 1970), Anowa (Longman, 1970), Our Sister Killjoy, Or, Reflections from a Black-Eyed Squint (Longman, 1977), Birds and Other Stories (1987), Changes (Heinemann, 1991), An Angry Letter in January and Other Poems (Dangaroo Press, 1992), The Girl Who Can and Other Stories (1997), Diplomatic Pounds and Other Stories (Ayebia Clark Publishing, 2012), and After the Ceremonies: New and Selected Poems (University of Nebraska Press, 2017). In 1974 she became a fellow in Creative Writing at Stanford University where she also worked as a consulting professor at the Phelps-Stokes fund’s  Ethnic Studies Program. She has taught at many colleges including the University of Ghana, Cape Coast University, Hamilton College, Brown, Xavier University, Mount Holyoke, Smith, Oberlin, Hamilton, and Brandeis. She was also the minister of education for Ghana under the Jerry Rawlings administration.

Biography:

Kofi Awoonor was born George Awoonor-Williams in Wheta, Ghana, to Ewe parents. He was a poet, literary critic, professor of comparative literature and served as an ambassador for Ghana. Awoonor earned a BA from University College of Ghana, an MA from University College, London, and a PhD in comparative literature from SUNY Stony Brook. He is the author of novels, plays, political essays, literary criticism, and several volumes of poetry, including Rediscovery and Other Poems (1964), Night of My Blood (1971), Ride Me, Memory (1973), The House by the Sea (1978), The Latin American and Caribbean Notebook (1992), and a volume of collected poems, Until the Morning After (1987).

Awoonor’s grandmother was an Ewe dirge singer, and the form of his early poetry draws from the Ewe oral tradition. He translated Ewe poetry in his critical study Guardians of the Sacred Word and Ewe Poetry (1974). Other works of literary criticism include The Breast of the Earth: A Survey of the History, Culture, and Literature of Africa South of the Sahara (1975).

In the early 1970s, Awoonor served as chairman of the Department of Comparative Literature at SUNY Stony Book. He returned to Ghana in 1975 to teach at University College of Cape Coast. In Ghana, he was arrested and tried for suspected involvement in a coup. He was imprisoned without trial and was later released; he wrote about his time in jail in The House by the Sea. Awoonor resumed teaching after his sentence was remitted. In the 1980s, he was the Ghanaian ambassador to Brazil and Cuba and served as ambassador to the United Nations from 1990 to 1994; in 1990 he published Ghana: A Political History from Pre-European to Modern Times.

Awoonor is author of the novels This Earth, My Brother… (1971) and Comes the Voyager at Last: A Tale of Return to Africa (1992). He died in the Westgate shopping mall attack in Kenya in September 2013.

Bio: Amina Bakouri was born in 1969 in Taza, Morocco. She is most well known for writing contemporary women’s poetry through the lens of the Arab tradition where she challenges patriarchal authority. Her poetry collection, Ra'ian Ya'tika Lmadih, was published in 2002. She received her Ph.D. in Arab literature from the Faculty of letters, Rabat, Morocco. Like other contemporary Moroccan female writers, Bakouri uses complex interrelationships between different texts as a guide to literary interpretation, an approach that is largely connected to Morocco’s past poetic memory.

Bio: Ahmed Barakat was born in 1960 in Casablanca, Morocco. He worked as a journalist for the Moroccan newspaper, Bayane Al Yawm, until his death in 1994 at the age of 34. He published two poetry collections including Abadan lan Ussai’da Azzilzal (Never will I sustain the schism). His poems, “Afterwards,” “Black Pain” and “The Torn Flag” were translated by Norddine Zouitni in 2012 and published in Poems for the Millennium, an anthology of traditional and experimental literary texts by North African writers. He was known for championing the prose poem in Morocco and is considered the first writer in the country to write a manifesto defending and celebrating this poetic form. The manifesto, titled “We Are Diggers of Wells, or the Unsigned Manifesto,” was written in 1993 during a poetry festival of Salé and has since been known as the Salé prose poem manifesto. In his poetry, the writer reflected on the urban cosmopolitan experience, work that is often regarded as a tribute to the city of Casablanca.

Bio: Samiya Bashir was born in 1970 in Ypsilanti, Michigan. A professor and lesbian poet, she is the author of poetry chapbooks Wearing Shorts on the First Day of Spring (1999), American Visa (2001) and Teasing Crow (2006). Her full-length collections include Where the Apple Falls (2005), Gospel (2009), a Lambda Literary Award finalist, and Field Theories (2017), which won the Oregon Book Award. As an activist, her work focuses on civil rights struggles and engages multiple landscapes of her own queer identity and politics. Bashir attended the University of California, Berkeley in 1994 where she received her BA in Literature of American Ethnic Cultures and served as Poet Laureate. In 2011, she studied Poetry for the People, an arts/activism program founded by June Jordan, in the University of Michigan. She was the first black woman to be awarded the Rome Prize by the American Academy in Rome in 2019. She joined the Reed College faculty in 2012, where she teaches poetry writing.

Bio: Tahar Bekri was born in 1951 in Gabès, Tunisia. A poet and literary critic, he has published several poetry collections, including La nostalgie des rosiers sauvages (2014) and Mûrier triste dans le printemps arabe (2016). Important themes in his work include exile, wandering, discovery of new worlds, and the reinvention of cultures. In 1970, he obtained his BA in Modern Literature from the University of Tunis. Considered one of the leading voices of contemporary North African literature, Bekri’s work has been the subject of academic research and translated into several languages (Russian, English, Italian, Spanish, Turkish, etc). In 1993, he was awarded the Order of Cultural Merit by the Tunisian Republic and in 2018, became the laureate of the Benjamin Fondane International Prize for Francophone Literature.

Bio: Mustapha Benfodil was born in 1968 in Relizane, Algeria. A playwright, novelist, and poet, he is well known for representing contemporary revolutionary Algerian writing and activism. His poem "To the health of the Republic!," which was written in tribute to assassinated writer Tahar Djaout, earned him the Special Jury Prize at the 5th Poésiades de Béjaïa in 1993. His other works include Kafkain Cocktail: Black Poetry and Pales vénustés de barracks, written during his military service in Sidi Bel Abbès and Djelfa. He went to the University of Sciences and Technology Houari Boumediiène for his Maths baccalaureate in 1987. With provocative and transgressive humor, he creates work that examines the political tension and economic crisis of his country. Benfodil is a journalist at El Watan and was awarded the Mohammed-Dib 2020 prize, which rewards authors writing in Arabic, Amazigh, and French.

Bio: Robert Berold was born in 1984 in Johannesburg, South Africa. Bio: Bate Besong was born in 1954 in Mamfe (Manyu Division), Cameroon. Among his collections of poetry are The Grains of Bobe Ngom Jua (1986), Obasinjom Warrior with Poems after Detention (1991) and Disgrace: Autobiographical Narcissus and Emanya-nkpe (2007). He went to the University of Calabar in Nigeria for his Masters and later received his PhD in Literary Studies from the same university. As a playwright and poet, he is widely known for his stance on art as a political fighting tool and his writings as a way to indict and criticize corrupt governance. He faced persecution as a result of his militant activism and was kidnapped and released in 1992. In 1992, he won the Association of Nigerian Authors' Prize for his Cameroonian drama, Requiem for the Last Kaiser. He was a lecturer at the University of Buea from 1999 until his death in 2007.

Bio: Juan Balboa Boneke was born in 1938 in Rebola, Equatorial Guinea. Writer and politician, he is the author of Sueños en mi selva: Antología poética (Dreams in My Jungle, 1987), O’Boriba (el exiliado) (O’Boriba [The Exiled], 1982), Requiebros (Flirtations, 1994), among others. He served as Minister under the presidency of Teodoro Obiang Nguema until he was forced to leave under the regimes of both Marcaís and Obiang. He went into exile in Palma de Mallorca and the theme of exile was central in his work. Boneke’s writing has also been regarded as political, with the writer advocating for the freedom to criticize dictatorship, corruption, and violence in his country with the hope to build a better nation. He obtained a Social degree from the University from Granada (Spain). In 2014, he died in Valencia, Spain.

Bio: Kola Boof was born in 1969 in Omdurman, Sudan. After her adoption in 1979, she relocated to Washington, D.C where she was a Psychiatric Out-Patient until she was 17. Novelist and poet, she is the author of the poetry collection “Every Little Bit Hurts” (1995), which has been regarded as a provocative work of art for its political and sexual connotations. Her work is known to explore religion, the sexuality of African women, the treatment of women in Islamic countries, and Sudanese cultural history. Her essay “I Am My Own Daughter” won the Swedish Woman to Woman Literary Award in 2007. Over the years, there have been controversies surrounding her involvement in international politics and diplomatic relations, and Boof’s writings have served as ways of activism and a means to render her own account.

Bio: Breyten Breytenbach was born 1939 in Bonnievale in Eastern Cape, South Africa. He has published more than fifty books, including books of poetry, novels, journals and a memoir. Some of his poetry collections include The Iron Cow Must Sweat (Die ysterkoei moet sweet) (1964), In Africa even the flies are happy (1978), Nine Landscapes of our Times Bequeathed to a Beloved (1993). He went to university of Cape Town where he studied Philosophy and Painting. In 2017, he was selected as Laureate of the Zbigniew Herbert International Literary Award. Breytenbach is well known for his political activism, especially his active involvement in the anti-apartheid movement in the 1960s and 1970s. Following his increased radicalization, he was arrested, charged with terrorism, convicted, and in November 1975 received a nine-year sentence until he was summarily freed in December 1982 and he moved to Paris, where he lives with his wife.

Bio: Abena Busia was born 1953 in Accra, Ghana. Her published works include Testimonies of Exile (1990) and Traces of a Life: A Collection of Elegies and Praise Poems (2008). In 2017, she was appointed Ghana's ambassador to Brazil. She was a Professor of English at Rutgers University for forty years until her retirement in 2021.

Bio: Bole Butake was born in 1947 in Nkor Noni, North West Province of Cameroon. Bio: Leila Chatti is a Tunisian-American writer and author of Deluge (2020), her debut full-length poetry collection that explores themes of illness, grief, misogyny, and religious beliefs. Her other publications are Tunsiya/Amrikiya (2018) and Ebb (2018), a chapbook part of the anthology of emerging African poets by African Poetry Book Fund. She graduated from Michigan State University in 2011 and in 2015, received her M.F.A. from North Carolina State University, where she was awarded the Academy of American Poets Prize. Her poems, which blend personal narrative with the close examination of the enactment of faith and its complexities, have received numerous prizes including the Pushcart Prize. She lives in Cincinnati, Ohio, where she is pursuing a PhD in creative writing at the University of Cincinnati as a Provost Fellow.

Bio: Syl Cheney-Coker was born in 1945 in Freetown, Seirra Leone. Bio: Jeremy Cronin was born 1949 in Durban, South Africa and raised in a middle-class white family in Simonstown. He is the author of More than a Casual Contact (2006), Inside and Out (1999), and Even the Dead (1997). In July 1976, Cronin was incarcerated for his anti-apartheid activities against the state by working with banned liberation organizations. His work examines the freedom struggle, political and emotional landscape of the South African experience. He was released in May 1983. He became a Member of Parliament in 1999 and in 2012, he was appointed the Deputy Minister of Transport and Public Works. He holds a BA degree from the University of Cape Town and studied at the Sorbonne University in Paris, France between 1972 and 1974. He taught Philosophy at the University of Cape Town, where he coedited the volume, Ideologies of Politics.

Bio: Ruy Duarte de Carvalho was born 1941 in Santarém, Portugal and grew up in Namibe, south of Angola. His writings captured experiences of the Kuvale people of southern Angola, including their nomadic pastoral way of life and traditions. Poet, film director, and anthropologist, he was actively involved in Angola’s freedom fight. He received his diploma and doctorate from the School of High Studies in Social Sciences, Paris in 1982 and 1986 respectively. Considered one of Angola’s most prestigious poets, he devoted himself to the study of photography and traditional oral poetry. He taught at Luanda, Coimbra, Sao Paulo, Paris and Berkely until he moved to Swakopmund, Namibia where he died in 2010.

Bio: Koumanthio Zeinab Diallo was born 1956 in Labé, Guinea and grew up in the Fulani culture of ancient Fouta Djallon. Bio: Mbella Sonne Dipoko was born in 1936 in Douala, Cameroon. He is the author of the poetry collection Black and White in Love (1972). His literary portfolio consists of writings grounded in militant ideals as well as overt sexuality; the latter has received both praise and criticism for its eroticism. A poet and novelist, he went to University of Paris for his studies in Law and Economics, but decided to pursue writing full time. Considered one of the foremost writers of Anglophone Cameroonian literature, Dipoko’s work has been widely anthologized. He returned from the West in 1985 and in 1991 and was enthroned as the chief of Misaka, a position previously held by his late father. He died in 2009 in Tiko, Cameroon.

Bio: Dladla Angifi was born in 1950 in Gauteng, South Africa. Bio: Inua Ellams was born 1984 in Jos, Nigeria and moved to England with his family when he was 12. Bio: John Eppel was born 1947 in Lydenburg, South Africa and grew up at Colleen Bawn, Zimbabwe. Bio: Ashur Etwebi was born 1952 in Tripoli, Libya. Etwebi was a professor of medicine at the University of Zawia and he now lives in Norway.

Bio: Corsino António Fortes was born 1933 in Mindelo, Cape Verde. Poet and diplomat, he is known to explore his country’s independence and path to liberation in his writings, as well as themes of exile, oppression and identity. His first book, Pão & Fonema (1974), addressed the conditions of island populations under Portuguese rule where Cape Verdeans suffered from hunger. The poet engages the political and cultural aspects of the Cape Verdean life and captures the islands' distinctive African nature. Fortes served as the first Ambassador of Cape Verde to Portugal from 1975 until 1981. He was the president of the Association of Cape Verde Writers (2003-2006) and the founder of Cape Verdean Academy of Letters. He studied Law at the University of Lisbon in 1966 and worked as a professor and judge of the Labour Court.

Bio: Harry Garuba was born 1958 in Akure, Nigeria. At 24, he published his debut collection, Shadow and Dream and Other Poems (1982) which was first runner-up in the inaugural All-Africa Okigbo prize for poetry. In 1988, he received his MA and PhD from University of Ibadan, where he also served as an assistant lecturer in the English department from 1981 to 1997. Garuba was a member of the editorial advisory board of the Heinemann African Writers Series and was well known for his active interest in African and postcolonial literatures. In 1998, he moved to South Africa and joined the faculty at University of Cape Town in 2001. He died Cape Town at the age of 61.

Bio: Aracelis Girmay was born 1977 in Santa Ana, CA to an American mother and Ethiopian father. Her first collection Teeth (2007) won the Great Lakes Colleges Association New Writers Award. She went to Connecticut College for her undergrad in documentary studies and received her MFA from New York University. In 2011, Girmay was awarded a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts, and in 2015 she received a Whiting Award for Poetry. She is currently the Editor-at-Large for BOA Editions' Blessing the Boats Selections, and she also serves on the editorial board of the African Poetry Book Fund. She teaches at Hampshire College and lives in New York City.

Bio: Werewere Liking was born 1950 in Cameroon. She is most well known for her experimental and avant-garde style of writing. Considered one of the leading figures of women writers in Francophone Africa, she founded Ki-Yi Mbocke Village (meaning "ultimate universal knowledge" in Bassa), a training center and community of artists including writers, painters, sculptors and more. In 2002, she was the recipient of the Prince Claus Award for her contributions to cultural and societal development. Writer, performer, and playwright, Liking has championed Panafricanism over the years, and she employs diverse artistic expressions to transcend cultural differences and celebrate African authenticity.

Bio: Josué Guébo was born 1972 in Abidjan, Côte d’Ivoire. A French poet, he is the author of several poetry collections, some of which have been translated into English. Bio: Mafika Pascal Gwala was born 1946 in Verulam, South Africa. He is most well known for his involvement in the anti-apartheid and Black Consciousness movement. Poet and editor, he was a founding member of the Mpumalanga Arts Ensemble based in Hammarsdale. In 2007, Gwala received The SALA Literary Lifetime Award. He passed away on 6 September 2014 in Mpumalanga, South Africa.

Bio: Reesom Haile was born 1946 in Eritrea. Hi first poetry collection, Waza ms qumneger ntnsae hager (Tragicomedies for Resurrecting a Nation), was the recipient of the 1998 Raimok Prize, Eritrea’s highest literary award. He was in exile for twenty years during Eritrea’s war for independence from Ethiopia and returned to Eritrea in 1994. His writings examine Africa’s colonial past, civic responsibility and the struggle for national independence. A former Poet Laureate of Eritrea, he is widely recognized for his use of Tigrinya, one of Eritrea's main languages and his championing of the use of African vernaculars in creative expression rather than colonial languages. Haile earned his doctorate in Media Ecology from New York University. He died in 2003.

Bio: Peter Horn was born 1934 in Teplice, Czech. He is most well known for his anti-Apartheid poetry, which caused him to face disciplinary hearings and threats of deportation. His work envisions a multiracial society, advocates for freedom, and captures the experiences of the oppressed. He went to the University of Witwatersrand where he pursued a doctorate in German Studies (1970). In 2000, he was a Finalist for the Caine Prize for African Literature. He was the recipient of the 2011 SALA Literary Lifetime Award for his contribution to literature in South Africa. Bio: Dannabang Kuwabong was born 1955 in Nanville, the Upper West Region of Ghana. Bio: Kojo Laing was born 1946 in Kumasi, Ghana. One of Ghana’s leading poets and novelists, he is the author of the 1989 poetry collection Godhorse. His work has been praised for its linguistic originality where he takes a hybrid approach by blending English with Pidgin and vernacular language. Laing received his diploma in Management from the College of Management in Ghana before attending Birmingham University, England for his studies in rural management. In 1968, he graduated from Glasgow University with an MA in Political Science and History. Laing was the recipient of the National Poetry Prize Valco Award in 1976 and the 1985 National Novel Prize by the Ghana Association of Writers. He died in Ghana on 20 April 2017.

Bio: Lara Alda was born 1930 in Benguela, in the Portuguese colony of Angola. Poet, essayist and political activist, she writes with a sense of social consciousness on a variety of themes including memories of her own childhood, motherhood, racial identity, and national liberation. She is the author of Poemas (1966), Tempo da Chuva (1973), Poesia (1979), and Poemas (1984) (her collected poems), all of which were published posthumously in Portuguese. She studied in the department of medicine at the University of Lisbon and the University of Coimbra. The Alda Lara Prize (in Portuguese, Prémio Alda Lara) was established in her honour. She died at the age of thirty-two in Cambambe Angola, after her return from Portugal where she lived for 13 years.

Bio: Ana Mafalda Leite was born 1956 in Aveiro, Portugal. Bio: Liyou Libsekal was born in 1990 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Poet and essayist, she is the author of chapbook, Bearing Heavy Things (2015), part of the African Poetry Book Fund’s New Generation African Poets series. Bio: Alain Mabanckou was born in Republic of the Congo and grew up in Pointe Noire. A novelist, poet, and academic, Mabanckou is one of the most recognized writers in French contemporary literature. He teaches literature and creative writing in the Department of French & Francophone Studies and African Studies Center at University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).

Bio: Marjorie Phyllis Oludhe Macgoye was born 1928 in Southhampton, England. Bio: Makombo Bamboté was born in 1932 at Ouadda in the Haute-Kotto region. He is regarded as the first writer from Central African Republic to be published. His debut poetry collection is La poésie est dans l'histoire, which was published in 1960. He also authored the volume, Chant funèbre pour un héros d'Afrique, in 1962. Francophone poet, novelist and short story writer, he explored themes of identity, colonization, and the history of Central South Africans. He went to France in 1949 where he studied at École des hautes études en sciences sociales. Bamboté was appointed as an ambassador to UNESCO after General Jean-Bédel Bokassa's coup in 1974. He also served as a professor of African literature at the University of Laval. He died in 2016 in Quebec.

Bio: Juliana Makuchi Nfah-Abbenyi was born in 1958 in the South-West Province of Cameroon and raised in North West Province. Writer and critic, she is the author of Our Madness, Not Mine: Stories of Cameroon (1999), The Sacred Door and Other Stories: Cameroon Folktales of the Beba (2008), among others. In her work, she offers a complex exploration of African stereotypes, gender inequalities grounded in cultural and political contexts and a critique of the postcolonial Cameroonian identity. She received her B.A. in Bilingual Letters, English & French and MA in African Literature from the University of Yaounde. She also holds a doctorate in Comparative Literature from McGill University in Montreal, Canada, after which she immigrated to the United States. From 2012-2018, she served on the Executive Council of the African Literature Association (ALA). She is Distinguished Professor of English and Comparative Literature in the Department of English at North Carolina State University.

Bio: Chris Mann was born in Port Elizabeth, South Africa. Poet, playwright, and musician, he has published several collections of poetry including First Poems (1979) and A New Book of South African Verse (1979). His third volume, New Shades (1982) was the recipient of the Olive Schreiner Prize. In 2007, he received the Thomas Pringle Award for Poetry and in 2019, he was awarded the Patricia Schonstein Poetry in McGregor Prize. He attended the University of the Witwatersrand where he studied English and Philosophy. He also went to Oxford University where he earned his MA in English Language and Literature. He is the founder of Wordfest, developed as part of the National Arts Festival to celebrate languages and literature. Mann was the first Professor of Poetry at Rhodes University, where he lectured from 1977 to 1980. He died in 2021 in Makhanda, Eastern Cape.

Bio: Rethabile Masilo was born in 1961 in Morija, Lesotho. He fled Lesotho to the United States in 1981, and as a student refugee, he received a BSc in Biology from Maryville College in Tennessee in 1986. He relocated and settled in Paris, France in 1987. His poetry draws attention to the grief and trauma associated with Lesotho’s political struggles. He is the author of Waslap (2015), which won the Glenna Luschei Prize for African Poetry. He is also the recipient of the Dalro First Prize in poetry and the Thomas Pringle Award for Poetry. Masilo is the co-editor of literary journal, Canopic Jar.

Bio: Édouard Maunick was born in 1931 in Flacq District, Mauritius. He is the author of several poetry collections including Les Oiseaux du Sang (1954), De Sable et de Cendre: Poèmes (1996) and Mascaret ou Le livre de la mer et de la mort, which was influenced by the Nigeria-Biafra war. Exile, captivity, history and identity are central themes in his work. After attending teacher's training college, he taught for nine years and worked as a librarian for the Municipality of Port Louis. At age twenty-nine, he moved from Port Louis to Europe in 1960 where he worked as writer and director for Coopération Radiophonique. Poet, critic and translator, he is the recipient of the 2003 Grand prix de la francophonie and the 1977 Apollinaire Prize for Poetry. He joined UNESCO in 1970 and served as the director of UNESCO collection of representative literary works and was a member of the Haut conseil de la Francophonie and a Chevalier des Arts et Lettres. Maunick was appointed as Mauritian ambassador to South Africa in 1994. He died in 2021 in Paris.

Bio: Mukoma Wa Ngugi was born in Evanston, Illinois in 1971, and grew up in Kenya. Bio: Esther Nirina was born in 1932 on the central highlands of Madagascar. From 1953 to 1983, she lived and worked as a librarian at Orléans, France. She returned from France in 1990 and died in 2004 in Antananarivo, Madagascar.

Bio: Atukwei Okai was born in 1941 in Accra, Ghana. His first collection of poems, Flowerfall, was published in June 1969. His other collections include Oath of the Fontonfrom and Other Poems (1971), Lorgorligi: Logarithms and Other Poems (1974), Freedom Symphony: Selected and New Love Poems (2008) and Mandela the Spear and Other Poems (2013). Okai’s poems have been translated into several languages and anthologized over the years. Rooted in oral tradition, his writings have been recognized as having Pan-Africanist vision. In 1961, on a scholarship from the government of President Kwame Nkrumah, he went to Moscow, where he earned his MA at Maxim Gorky Literature Institute in 1967. He later received his M.Phil from the School of Slavonic and East European Studies in London in 1971. He was Secretary-General of the Pan African Writers' Association in 1989. Okai died in 2018 in Accra.

    Biography:

    Gabriel Okara, a prize-winning author whose literary career spans six decades, is rightly hailed as the elder statesman of Nigerian literature. The first Modernist poet of anglophone Africa, he is best known for The Fisherman’s Invocation (1978), The Dreamer, His Vision (2005), and for his early experimental novel, The Voice (1964).

    Gabriel Okara was born at Bumoundi, Bayelsa State, in the Niger Delta in 1921 and educated at Government College Umuahia in Nigeria and Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois. He worked as a bookbinder and printer for Federal Government Press at Lagos, served as the director of cultural and information services for the short-lived Republic of Biafra, and was the general manager of the Rivers State newspaper and broadcasting corporations. He was an honorary member of the Pan-African Writers’ Association, a fellow of the Nigerian Academy of Letters, and served as a writer in residence at the University of Port Harcourt, Rivers State, Nigeria.

Bio: Ben Okri was born in 1959 in Minna, Nigeria. A novelist, playwright, and a poet, Okri is the author of the 1992 poetry collection An African Elegy. Bio: Niyi Osundare was born 1947 in Ikere, Nigeria. Poet, playwright and essayist, he has published many poetry collections including Moonsongs (1988) and Random Blues (2011). Bio: Nduka Otiono was born 1964 in Kano, Nigeria. His poetry collection, Voice in the Rainbow (1997) was a finalist for the ANA/Cadbury Poetry Prize. In 2019, he edited the anthology “Camouflage," which featured the best contemporary writing from Nigeria. Teacher and researcher, he obtained his BA and MA degrees from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria. He also received his PhD in English & Film Studies from the University of Alberta in 2011. Before relocating to Canada in 2006, he worked as a journalist in Nigeria and served as General Secretary of the Association of Nigerian Authors (ANA). He is a a two-time recipient of the Carnegie African Diaspora Fellowship (2015 and 2016). Otiono is an Assistant Professor at the Institute of African Studies, Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada.

Bio: Warsan Shire was born 1988 in Nairobi, Kenya. In 2017, her work was featured in the Penguin Modern Poets series, Your Family, Your Body. She is the first ever Young Poetry Laureate of London and in 2014, was chosen as the poet-in-residence for Queensland, Australia. A recipient of the inaugural Brunel International African Poetry Prize in 2013, she has a Bachelor of Arts degree in Creative Writing from London Metropolitan University. Her full-length debut collection, Bless the Daughter Raised by a Voice in Her Head, is forthcoming in March 2022. Residing in Los Angeles now, she works as the poetry editor for SPOOK magazine.

Bio: Noémia de Sousa was born 1926 in Catembe, near the city of Maputo, Mozambique. Known as the Mother of Mozambican poets, she is the author of Sangue Negro (Black Blood), published in 2001. Regarded as anti-colonial literature, her writings represent cultural nationalism and the resistance of African women under Portuguese colonial domination in the 1940s. Although she was jailed for her political activism, her literary contributions played a crucial role in creating awareness about the Moçambicanidade movement. Poet and newspaper editor, de Sousa edited the women’s pages of the newspaper O Brado Africano from 1949 to 1951. She left Mozambique in 1951 and settled permanently in Portugal, where she died in 2002.

Bio: Wole Soyinka was born in 1934 in Abeokuta in western Nigeria. He has published six collections of poetry including Idanre, and Other Poems (1967), Poems from Prison (1969), A Shuttle in the Crypt (1972) the long poem Ogun Abibiman (1976) and Mandela’s Earth and Other Poems (1988). He attended the University College Ibadan in 1954 and studied English literature, Greek, and Western history. In 1957, he went on to the University of Leeds in England where he continued his studies in English literature. He is most well known for his work as a playwright in which he engages Yoruba folklore and indigenous spiritual traditions. He also dramatizes political and social issues in Nigeria. He was the first African to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986. Following his political advocacy, he went into exile during the military coup of January 1966. He was later imprisoned until his release in October 1969.

Bio: Peter Wuteh Vakunta is a native of Bamunka-Ndop in the Northwest Region of the Republic of Cameroon. He earned his Ph.D. in French and Francophone Studies with a minor in linguistics from the University of Wisconsin Madison. Bio: Hope Wabuke was born 1981 in Minnesota. She has published three chapbooks: her (2019), The Leaving (2016), and Movement No.1 (2015). She went to Northwestern University in 2002 for her undergrad in Film and Media Studies and Creative Writing. Wabuke also received her MFA in Creative Writing from New York University in 2007. An Assistant Professor of English and Creative Writing, her research interests include African and African Diasporic Literature, Literary & Cultural Criticism and Women's and Gender Studies. A finalist for the 2015 Brunel University African Poetry Prize, she has received fellowships and awards from the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Book Critics Circle, Cave Canem, among others. She is the Poetry Editor for Ruminate Magazine and teaches at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

Bio: Kangsen Feka Wakai was born 1978 in Bamenda, Cameroon. He is the author of two poetry collections: Fragmented Melodies (2007) and Asphalt Effect (2007). Bio: Patricia Jabbeh Wesley was born 1955 in Monrovia, Liberia. She is the author is several poetry collections including Where the Road Turns (2010) and Praise song for my children: new and selected poems (2022). A Liberian civil war survivor, she explores themes of immigration, femininity, motherhood, displacement, war, and grief in her work. She incorporates African motifs and proverbs to capture the turmoil and recovery of her country’s struggle in war. She earned her BA at the University of Liberia and MS in English Education at Indiana University. She also pursued her PhD in Creative Writing at Western Michigan University. Wesley is the recipient of the 2010 Liberian Award for her poetry and her mentorship of young Liberians in the Diaspora. She is an Associate Professor of English, Creative Writing, and African Literature at Penn State University’s Altoona campus.

Bio: Ladé Wosornu was born 1937 in Galo-Sota, located in South Tongu District in the Volta region of Ghana. He is the author of the 1995 poetry collection, Ete?, A Woman of Africa and Other Poems. His other collections include: Journey Without End And Other Poems (1997) and Celestial Bride and other poems (2002). Bio: Wyk van Chris was born in 1957 in Soweto. He studied at Riverlea High School in Riverlea, Johannesburg. A critically acclaimed writer, he is the author of books such as Maria (1966), It is Time To Go Home (1979), Petroleum and the Orphaned Ostrich (1988), Oliver Tambo (1994), My Cousin Thabo (1995), April in the Cape of Storms (1996), The Year of the Tapeworm (1996), In Detention (2007), and others. He was awarded the Olive Schreiner Prize for his poetry collection titled "It Is Time to Go Home"(1979). He was also awarded prizes such as the Maskew Miller Longman Award and the Sanlam Literary Award. He died in Johannesburg on 3 October 2014.

Bio: Dan Wylie was born in 1959 in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe. His poetry collection, The Road Out (1996), won the 1998 Ingrid Jonker and Olive Schreiner prizes. His other works include Road Work (2007), Slow Fires (2013), and Raven Games (2017). Poet, novelist and essayist, he concentrates on ecological issues in his writings, with further interests in the history of Shaka Zulu and Zimbabwean literature. In 1995, he earned his Ph.D. on white myths of Shaka from Rhodes University, Makhanda, South Africa, where he remains Professor Emeritus.

Bio: Makhosazana Xaba was born in 1957 in Greytown, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. She is the author of These Hands (2005), Tongues of Their Mothers (2008) and The Alkalinity of Bottled Water (2019). Poet, essayist and short story writer, her work is infused with activism as she explores the political and social challenges of her country’s present and past. Trained as a midwife and psychiatric nurse, she has served and contributed nationally and globally to areas of women’s rights and gender. During the second state of emergency in 1986, she went into exile and returned to South Africa in 1990 with the African National Congress Women’s League. She edited the poetry anthology “Like the untouchable wind: an anthology of poems” (2016) and “Our Word, Our Worlds: Writing on Black South African Women Poets” (2020). Xaba earned her MA degree in creative writing from University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg.
